item.title: Twitch chat Client (part 2) [DRAFT]
item.description: Introduction We already implemented simple Twitch.tv Chat client in part 1 of tutorial, now we’re going to parse incoming IRC messages into “manageable” classes. Remember the Backusâ€“Naur form (BNF) form for IRC message format that we already saw in IRCv3 specification <message> ::= ['@' <tags> <SPACE>] [':' <prefix> <SPACE> ] <command> <params> <crlf> <tags> ::= <tag> [';' <tag>]* <tag> ::= <key> ['=' <escaped_value>] <key> ::= [ <client_prefix> ] [ <vendor> '/' ] <key_name> <client_prefix> ::= '+' <key_name> ::= <non-empty sequence of ascii letters, digits, hyphens ('-')> <escaped_value> ::= <sequence of zero or more bytes except NUL, CR, LF, semicolon (`;`) and SPACE> <vendor> ::= <host> This is the format that we will need to parse with fastparse library

item.title: Twitch chat Client (part 1)
item.description: Introduction In this 3 part tutorial series we’re going to explore TCP Connection handling; IRCv3 message parsing and connection handling for Twitch.tv Chat. Here in first part of the tutorial we’re going to implement IRC protocol Client for our Twitch.tv Chat Client. Prerequisites Basic understanding of TCP Protocol and Akka actors Research First of all, we should start with research: How to connect to IRC server How to send IRC messages.
